Expectation1: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation1: A carpenter is waiting for you to bring them the next load of lumber so they can continue their work without interruption.
Situation2: They quietly repeat a short mantra during their day without following the full ritual.
Story: I wiped the sweat from my brow, feeling the weight of the lumber pressing into my shoulder. The foreman’s voice echoed in my ears, “Hurry up, the carpenter’s waiting!” I could see the carpenter tapping his foot, glancing at his watch, anxious to keep the project moving. My muscles ached, but I pushed myself harder, knowing that any delay would slow everyone down. Yet, as I walked, I felt the familiar tug inside me—a reminder that I hadn’t performed my morning puja, only whispered a hurried mantra under my breath before leaving for work. My mother’s words echoed in my mind, “Never neglect your prayers, even on the busiest days.” The guilt gnawed at me. I wanted to stop, just for a moment, to close my eyes and recite the full prayer, to feel the peace it always brought me. But the demands of the site pressed in, the expectation to keep moving, to not let anyone down. My heart pounded with the struggle, torn between the world of bricks and beams and the quiet call of my faith.
